block.p: Dr. Laura Anne Hodes, a daughter of Dr. Cynthia Miller Hodes and Dr. David S. Hodes of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Alan Walter Dove, a son of Sarah W. Griffith of Severna Park, Md. and Thomas L. Dove of Kent Island, Md. The Rev. Charles R. Colwell performed the ceremony at the Zion Episcopal Church.

The bride, 28, graduated from Princeton University and received an M.D. degree last week from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. In June, she is to begin a residency in general surgery at Temple University Medical Center in Philadelphia. Her mother is a pediatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. Her father is a medical director in Nutley, N.J., with Roche Laboratories and a former chief of pediatric infectious diseases at Mount Sinai.

Dr. Laura Anne Hodes, a daughter of Dr. Cynthia Miller Hodes and Dr. David S. Hodes of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Alan Walter Dove, a son of Sarah W. Griffith of Severna Park, Md. and Thomas L. Dove of Kent Island, Md. The Rev. Charles R. Colwell performed the ceremony at the Zion Episcopal Church.

The bride, 28, graduated from Princeton University and received an M.D. degree last week from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. In June, she is to begin a residency in general surgery at Temple University Medical Center in Philadelphia. Her mother is a pediatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York. Her father is a medical director in Nutley, N.J., with Roche Laboratories and a former chief of pediatric infectious diseases at Mount Sinai.

The bridegroom, 31, is a contributing writer in New York for Nature Biotechnology and Nature Medicine. He graduated from Towson State University and received a Ph.D. in microbiology from Columbia. His mother is an administrative assistant at Arinc Research, a designer of air-traffic control systems in Annapolis, Md. His father is a technical editor at Sail and Chesapeake Bay magazines.

The couple met in December 1995 while attending a medical conference on viruses at Mount Sinai. Mr. Dove was a graduate student and Ms. Hodes was a research technician. ''I saw an empty seat,'' Ms. Hodes recalled, ''and the guy next to it was cute.'' Ms. Hodes and a female friend sat down. Bored, they began doodling in-jokes on their notepads.

In molecular biology, there is an enzyme called BGL2, which is pronounced Bagel 2. Mr. Dove noticed the two doodling women, and when a speaker mentioned BGL2, Mr. Dove quickly drew on his own notepad a picture of twin bagels. Mutual admiration ensued.
